title: 108_s2420
content: The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. Section 2110(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is an exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage. Section 2110(b)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to include certain non federally funded coverage for children. A State shall not exclude a child from being treated as a targeted vulnerable child who has access to high-cost coverage under a group health plan or health insurance coverage. The Social Security Act is amended to include targeted vulnerable children in the family's income for health plan charges. Amendments also change references to "targeted low-income" to "targeted vulnerable" and specify coverage for children above 200% of the poverty line. Effective date is October 1, 2004. SEC. 3. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. The amendment to the Social Security Act increases federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures under SCHIP. The limitation on expenditures for outreach strategies is waived for these states. The amendment to the Social Security Act increases federal financial participation for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures under SCHIP. The outreach strategies described in the clause include carrying out the same outreach strategies for children under title XIX, and the enhanced FMAP for a State shall be increased by 5 percentage points with respect to such expenditures. The outreach strategies for children under SCHIP include presumptive eligibility, 12-month continuous eligibility, and elimination of asset tests. The State does not apply any asset test for children's eligibility under title XIX and provides automatic renewal if no changes are reported. The Medicaid section of the Social Security Act is amended to allow for enhanced Federal medical assistance percentage for outreach strategies targeting individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance. The Federal medical assistance percentage is increased for states that implement outreach strategies for children under title XXI, including presumptive eligibility, 12-month continuous eligibility, and elimination of asset tests. The State does not apply asset tests for eligibility under title XXI. Automatic renewal of eligibility is provided if no changes are reported, effective October 1, 2004. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to increase funding for SCHIP. Effective October 1, 2004, the funding amounts are adjusted. SEC. 5 imposes limitations on payments to states with enrollment caps. Amendment to the Social Security Act limits payments to states with enrollment caps if they have not fully expended available allotments for child health assistance. Amendment to the Social Security Act restricts payments to states with enrollment caps if they have not fully spent available allotments for child health assistance. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2004. Amendment to the Social Security Act expands Medicaid managed care requirements to SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
